This makes total sense to me as a therapist. Our experiences are what our brain tells us. Sensations are processed in the brain. So, pain signals and temperature signals are being interpreted with a biased brain. This doesn't mean that the heat was actually diminished. So, if it were hot enough that it could leave a blister, for example, the person may believe it decreased the pain but they are still going to end up with a blister. I suppose it's nice to have the study, but this isn't really new information unless I'm missing some nuance to the study, which I admittedly have not read myself. I'm thinking this may be more interesting for dualists. I'm not inclined to believe the mind is a non-phydical thing. So, if we knew people reported experiencing less pain, and didn't think they were lying, I'm not sure what other outcome was possible here... unless you're a dualist and then we are just talking about a very different way of conceptualizing the mind.

this reminds me of the theory of manifestation, or even subliminals as we see on the internet today. its less about whats in it, but its more about making your brain believe its happening, therefore it will happen. if you make the title "have a smaller nose," your nose is unlikely to actually get any smaller but your brain gets tricked into thinking it is after time, because the messages are telling your brain that its happening, therefore it starts to actually believe it. you start to love your nose for what it actually is.

this is also a really good theory to use in positive affirmations. if you write down something like "i am happy," 10 times on a paper every day, your brain will start to rewire itself into believing its happy. if you write "i have an abundance of excitement in my life," your brain might start unconsciously seeking out excitement, therefore making it come true.

tricking your brain is great for many things ^^ the placebo effect is all about tricking the brain.

Oh, it is 100% real, and I could even be the study pig for this one. When I was 17, I had a really bad medical problem with incredible pain, so narcotics and all, of course, but the thing was, they started working too fast. I would swallow a pill, and within MINUTES, I would be asleep and out of pain. My mom told me it was probably just in my head, because, even with powerful medication, no way it woks that fast. And she was right, obviously, because, about a decade later, I had another medical thing go on where I took a lot fewer pain meds, so, when I actually did need them, they would take, like, half an hour to work. Sort of an extension of what you're talking about here, eh, because, when I was a teen, I got o used to the meds, and knew what they would do to me so well, that my brain started anticipating relief, and therefore creating i, before it was really happening.

I think the best and most obvious example of the placebo effect is a parent being able to kiss a child's injuries better. Does a kiss on a cut (over the bandage or next to the actual cut) actually relieve pain or help it heal? No. But because children don't understand medicine or biology and usually just trust what their parents tell them at that age, they believe the kiss takes away the pain and helps their injury heal faster, and they do show signs of pain relief.

There's no way parents would have been doing this for so long if it didn't do anything to even calm down their children. All it takes is trying it once and the child continuing to cry and scream in pain, likely feeling more severe than it is, for the parent to stop and find something else to help better.

Also, we can sort of see this in reverse with things like Munchausen syndrome. The brain is told something is wrong and thus the body emulates having that issue. If the brain believing your legs are paralyzed hard enough makes your body treat your legs like they're paralyzed, why would it be impossible for the brain to do the inverse, believing so hard that a cream can relieve pain that it actually will relieve the pain? Obviously there are limits, it can't make your legs stop being paralyzed if they truly were, but still.
